NEGF.NF: Well, I don't think that's quite right.
No, that's not the right answer.
No, that's not the correct answer.
No, you are on the wrong track.

NEUF.NUF: okay. but can you give me a little more on that?
Alright, but please give me a little more on this.
Kind of,but there is a little more you can add.
Yeah, but we need to try to cover a few more points
Almost there, Just give me a little more

Item.text: In this session, I'm going to ask some questions about why we use ANOVAs.
In conclusion, if your independent variable has more than two levels, use an ANOVA!

Rule.name: Start
Rule.description: This is the beginning of the conversation.

Rule.name: Opening
Rule.description: This rule delivers an opening pack if it is available.

Rule.name: NoMoreTutoringPack
Rule.description: Turns to final closing when all tutoring packs have been covered.

Rule.name: StartTutoring
Rule.description: Turns to the main question of the next tutoring pack.

Rule.name: AskMQ
Rule.description: Ask the main question, assuming that there is always at least one main question prepared for the tutor agent.

Rule.name: FB2MQGood
Rule.description: User's answer is ideal. Give feedback and turn to positive transition pack.

Rule.name: FB2MQBad
Rule.description: User's answer is bad. Give feedback and get into expectation.

Rule.name: FB2MQMetaCog
Rule.description: When user gives MetaCog, give MetaCog repsonse and get into expectation.

Rule.name: PumpBlank
Rule.description: User's answer is blank, give a pump.

Rule.name: TryMQRepeat
Rule.description: User wants to repeat the question. Look for the second main question.

Rule.name: FB2RepeatMQOther
Rule.description: When user asks to repeat the question, get into expectation if there no more main question.

Rule.name: FB2MQIrrelevant
Rule.description: User's answer is irrelevant. Give irrelevant response and get into expectation.

Rule.name: CheckConfusionOne
Rule.description: Check confusion.

Rule.name: CheckConfusionTwo
Rule.description: Check confusion.

Rule.name: FB2MQConfusionOne
Rule.description: Skip pumps sometimes.

Rule.name: FB2MQConfusionTwo
Rule.description: Skip pumps sometimes.

Rule.name: Pump
Rule.description: For all other situations, give a pump.

Rule.name: FB2PumpGood
Rule.description: User's answer is ideal. Closing current tutoring pack and find next tutoring pack.

Rule.name: FB2PumpBad
Rule.description: User's answer is bad. Student agrees and gives a bad answer. Tutor corrects and get into expectation.

Rule.name: FB2PumpOther
Rule.description: All other cases, get into expectation.

Rule.name: FB2MQOther
Rule.description: Skip pumps sometimes.

Rule.name: NoMoreExpectation
Rule.description: When no more expectation available, get into negative transition.

Rule.name: StartExpectation
Rule.description: Try to find a student hint when an expectation is available.

Rule.name: NoMoreTutorHint
Rule.description: Try to find a studentn prompt if there is not tutor hint.

Rule.name: TutorHint
Rule.description: Deliver tutor hint if there is any.

Rule.name: NoMoreTutorPrompt
Rule.description: Try to find a good answer to the expectation when no more prompt is available.

Rule.name: TutorPrompt
Rule.description: Deliver tutor prompt if there is any.

Rule.name: Assertion
Rule.description: Deliver assertion and get into another expectation.

Rule.name: NoAssertion
Rule.description: Get into another expectation if no assertion available.

Rule.name: FB2HintGood
Rule.description: User's answer is good to hint. Give feedback and turn to prompt.

Rule.name: FB2HintBad
Rule.description: User's answer is bad to hint. Student agent agrees wrongly. Tutor agent corrects. Turn to prompt.

Rule.name: FB2HintConfusion
Rule.description: User's prompt answer is bad, give feedback and turn to assertion.

Rule.name: CheckHintConfusione
Rule.description: All other hint reponses. Turn to prompt.

Rule.name: FB2HintOther
Rule.description: All other hint reponses. Turn to prompt.

Rule.name: FB2PromptGood
Rule.description: User's answer is good to the prompt. Give feedback and turn to assertion.

Rule.name: FB2PromptBad
Rule.description: User's prompt answer is bad, give feedback and turn to assertion.

Rule.name: FB2PromptOther
Rule.description: Any other prompt responses, give prompt answer and turn to assertion.

Rule.name: NegTransition
Rule.description: Negative transition to next tutoring pack.

Rule.name: PosTransition
Rule.description: Positive transition to next tutoring pack.

Rule.name: Closing
Rule.description: Final closing

Item.text: See if you can get this.
See if you know the answer to this.
I will give you some more time.
And can you add to that?
What else can you say about it?
Can you add anything to that?
Is there anything you can add to this?
And can you add to that?
Could you elaborate on that a little?
Please try to answer at least part of the question.
tell me what you know, and we'll go from there.
If you can at least try to answer, we can start building from there.
Try to answer, so that we have a starting point from which to build.
If you give me some sort of an answer, we can at least start from there and build.
Let's focus on the main idea.
Let me help you a little.
It's okay if you're confused, we will work together.
It seems like you may not understand the question.
I feel like you may be confused. That can happen.
Are you unsure of what to do? That's OK. We will work through it?

Question.text: If your independent variable has more than two levels, you must analyze it with an ANOVA. Why can you not use multiple t-tests?

Expectation.text: Each test has a chance of being wrong.

Answer.name: Expt1Good1
Answer.text: Each test has a chance of being wrong.

Hint.text: Each statistical test is based on probability, so what does p represent?

Prompt.text: p represents the chance of a type one error, which means each test you run has a chance of being what?

Expectation.text: More tests increases the probability of at least one being wrong.

Answer.name: Expt2Good1
Answer.text: More tests increases the probability of at least one being wrong.

Hint.text: If each test has a chance of being wrong, what happens if you run multiple tests?

Answer.name: Hint1Good1
Answer.text: More tests increases the probability of at least one being wrong.

Prompt.text: As you run more statistical tests, what happens to the likelihood that at least one is wrong?

Expectation.text: An ANOVA uses an omnibus F test to avoid capitalizing on chance.

Answer.name: Expt3Good1
Answer.text: ANOVA uses an omnibus F test to avoid capitalizing on chance.

Hint.text: How does an ANOVA avoid capitalizing on chance?

Answer.name: Hint1Good1
Answer.text: By using an omnibus F test.

Prompt.text: Instead of multiple t-tests, an ANOVA uses what kind of test?

Misconception.text: Youâ€™ll be likely to make an error.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 1
ITEM.mattextS: Welcome class. <pause/> When we ended last time, _NAMES1_ had a question about comparing more than two groups.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 2
ITEM.mattextS: Yeah, a question you totally dodged.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 3
ITEM.mattextS: _NAMES1_'s question was about using multiple t tests to compare multiple groups. <pause/>
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 3-2
ITEM.mattextS: For example, let's imagine we are comparing Freshmen, Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors. We want to know if there is a difference in the amount of sleep they get per night. <pause/>
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 3-3
ITEM.mattextS: In this case we have multiple groups, which means we need to make multiple comparisons. Specifically, we have four groups and six comparisons.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 3-4
ITEM.mattextS: The four groups are Freshman, Sophomore, Junior, and Senior.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 3-5
ITEM.mattextS: The six comparisons are Freshman vs. Sophomore, Freshman vs. Junior, Freshman vs. Senior, Sophomore vs. Junior, Sophomore vs. Senior, and Junior vs. Senior.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 4
ITEM.mattextS: So, can you use multiple t tests to compare those groups?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 5
ITEM.mattextS: Actually, we should not use multiple t-tests to make multiple comparisons.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 6
ITEM.mattextS: Why not?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 7
ITEM.mattextS: Let me explain why not with an example.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 8
ITEM.mattextS: Consider the following scenario in which you can pick between two games: <pause/> in game 1, you have a 5% chance of winning. <pause/> in game 2, you have a 5% chance of winning in addition to another 5% chance of winning. <pause/> Which game do you want to play? That is, which game gives you a higher chance of winning?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 9
ITEM.mattextS: <eyeswide/> I'm having trouble understanding this game.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 10
ITEM.mattextS: Ok, let's make this hypothetical game more concrete. <pause/>
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 10-1
ITEM.mattextS: You have just over a 5% chance of rolling an 11 on a pair of dice, right?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 10-2
ITEM.mattextS: I guess.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 11
ITEM.mattextS: If you win by rolling an 11, would you rather get one chance to roll <pause/>--as represented in Game 1--<pause/> or two chances to roll<pause/>--as represented in Game 2?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 12
ITEM.mattextS: This is easily the dumbest question you've ever asked.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 13
ITEM.mattextS: Game 2, obviously.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 14
ITEM.mattextS: Okay. <pause/> Why?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 15
ITEM.mattextS: More chances to win.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 16
ITEM.mattextS: Exactly. You're capitalizing on chance. <pause/> The more opportunities you get, the more chances you have to win.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 17
ITEM.mattextS: So what does this have to do with _NAMES1_'s original question?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 18
ITEM.mattextS: When we're making multiple comparisons, each statistical test has a probability of error associated with it, right?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 19
ITEM.mattextS: You mean the p value?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 20
ITEM.mattextS: Precisely. <pause/>There is always a possibility that your results are simply due to chance.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 21
ITEM.mattextS: Okay. Can we stop for a second? I remember p values but I'm having a hard time making the connection.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 22
ITEM.mattextS: No problem. <pause/>
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 22-2
ITEM.mattextS: So, let's go back to our study comparing the sleep habits of Freshmen, Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors. <pause/>
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 22-3
ITEM.mattextS: We use a t-test to compare each group. Let's say that the result of each t-test is p = .05.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 23
ITEM.mattextS: Alright.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 24
ITEM.mattextS: That means each comparison has a 5% probability of being due to chance, right?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 25
ITEM.mattextS: That's right.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 26
ITEM.mattextS: So, each additional test you conduct is like rolling the dice again. <pause/> One comparison has a 95% chance of being correct, or a 5% chance of being a Type 1 error.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 26-2
ITEM.mattextS: But the probability of two comparisons both being correct is .95 times .95, or .95 squared, which is about 90%.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 26-3
ITEM.mattextS: Wow, so now we're at a 10% chance of making a Type 1 error?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 26-4
ITEM.mattextS: Right. <pause/> And the probability of three comparisons all being right is .95 cubed, which is about 86%, and so on. <pause/> By the time we get to 6 comparisons, the chance of all of them being right is just 74%.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 27
ITEM.mattextS: So, multiple tests means more chances that at least one test result is wrong.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 28
ITEM.mattextS: That's exactly right.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 29
ITEM.mattextS: Okay, that makes sense. <pause/> So, what do we do about it?
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 29-2
ITEM.mattextS: Find a new line of work.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.

ITEM.TITLE: Slide 30
ITEM.mattextS: We use the next inferential test we're going to learn: the Analysis of Variance, or ANOVA.
ITEM.mattextD: Good afternoon, class. We've talked about between subjects designs, where each participant only recieves one level of the independent variable.
